comment:
This LDI-sourced whiskey uses LDI's high-rye recipe, which is definitely how I prefer my bourbon. The tall, thin bottle brings a generic look to the increasingly infamous LDI bourbon. The alcohol hit up front definitely started this pour on a weak note for me. But it settled into a good traditional corn and spice flavor.
        Without the big rye / pepper influence I'm tempted to call this a smooth, easy introductory drink for someone exploring past the Beam hegemony. Instead I'll stick with it being a decent option in the crowded mid-range of the Bourbon world. Perhaps a little over-priced for a common, but enjoyable flavor.
http://www.reddit.com/r/bourbon/comments/2hutm9/redemption_highrye_bourbon_review_12/
Spices, spices, spices! Ginger, clove, vanilla, and a little bit peppery; rich and full-bodied, Redemption's High Rye Bourbon makes fantastic whisky caramels. Or just a simple sipping drink.

Smooth pleasant nose. Perfectly balanced taste of bourbon with spicy rye. Somewhat marred by a sharpness that isn't dulled by a bit of water.  Would be good base for a mixer or cocktail.. not great for sipping alone.

Nose is spice forward, vanilla, caramel, and musty wood.  I also am reminded of fresh oregano from the garden.

Taste is rye spice, wood, musty grains, and a small amount of vanilla.  

Finish is more rye, flat, but tasty.
I was hoping for a little more. It has definite spiciness. Oily that leads to a hint of caramel and sweetness on the end.
Not much to it. High burn, initial spice doesn't last
Flavor, then burn and done.  Faster than I'd like.

Received as a gift. Tried straight on rocks and in cocktail. Very smooth for a "high Rye". Disappointed! Best in cocktail that I made. For the price it's one that will be drank, but Wild Turkey, Beam, or Daniels would be better!
some good initial spice. needs to be aged a few more years
Surprisingly varied nose and mouth-feel for such a young one. Couldn’t pass up the price to try it ($26 at Richfield Liquors). Will have to see if it holds up to mixing as well.
Best enjoyed straight at room temperature. Mixing or chilling masks the flavors easily.

Redemption High Rye has a lighter amber appearance, with thin alcohol sheeting (not legs). Aroma is of peppery spice and light generalized whiskey aroma, with some bee's wax & honeycomb. Taste is of spiced whiskey, with more spearmint than rye, from my reckoning. Honey and dried flowers show up, too. Mouthfeel is medium, and Redemption High Rye finishes with a quick drop, although there is an underlying pepper rye linger. A bourbon, aged "no less than one year"? Odd. This new bottle design (2016) has a cork stopper cap and a Bulleit-style medicine bottle. RJT
Really like this one. Very tasty and only $25
Strong presentation, good rye feel it in the nose
Great with a capful of Cointreau and a bada- bing cherry!
Three measures mixed with a splash of Peychaud bitters and a measure of Cointreau, garnished with a Bada-Bing cherry, and you have a nice variation on an Old Fashioned without a lot of fuss!
Nice, smooth for a rye. Recommended by Laurie
Disappointing as a rye.l, but I guess it is really a bourbon. I liked their Rye.
Spicy, corny sweetness, telltale MGP dill, youthful with some sawdust, medium finish with sugary vanilla and more young oak. Not my first choice, not my last.
Good intro to rye. Spicy, but mellowed by the bourbon sweet. Taste of the bark from a sugar cane.
Not bad, but not really spicy like a rye. Just a touch of spicy heat and a ton of caramel sweetness
3.5 stars easily, definitely a rye, and definitely spicy.
Cola nilla in the front, a quick flash of spice next, dominates the palate.  Sweet anise and a quick lite finish

Neat. This was an interesting taste. I was leery of trying based on reviews. It was real solid. Not great and certainly not bad. 

"0-1: Beyond bad. Complete waste of money according to my tastebuds. 
2: Bad. Simply not my taste
2.5: Sub-par. Ill drink it... but only because its whiskey.
3: Good. Decent stuff, but not a rebuy
3.5: Very good. I might buy again
4: Excellent: Will be purchasing a bottle asap
4.5: Incredible: top of the purchase list
5:Amazing: cost and taste are worth every cent"
The perfect blend of a rye and bourbon for an incredible price!
Lots of spice up front but a smooth finish. I like this for a Rye, could see being really good as a mixer

Nose: corn and vanilla. 
Palate: oak, sweetness, slight spice. Quick finish. Better than expected.
This is a very smooth rye. Not a big bite on finish. I get nice taste and hints of vanilla on tongue. Overall one of my favorites so far.
Good bourbon for the price. It's got good flavor, but too much burn for drinking straight. Great as a mixer though.

Very disappointed with this one since I like their Rye a lot.  Very little spice for a high Rye mashbill.  I found it boring and very plain. Finnish is almost nonexistent. Will be using this for a mixed only.

Found this at a good price (21$$) so elected to get the bottle(proof=92, batch 119) as a high rye bourbon this falls in line with my recent samplings of hi corn ryes, hi rye-corn etc.  Totally by accident of course(wink wink).

  Ryan's front page notes seem pretty spot on,   yes the  "cinnamon, anise, clove" rye influence opens up quickly and the late subtle "undertones of fennel, dill and mint" eventually arrive.     The complexity and variety for a "youngin" is fairly impressive, and the base bourbon stays put to the back ground so to speak. 

Not completely unlike the Old Forester Rye also found at a noteworthy price point as well, there are some interesting rye-corn-malt notes at play in Redemption High Rye that I think totally redeems it in the face of other, pricier,  "genteel" ryes and bourbon-rye treatments.  Yes it's Indiana "heartland" rye  whiskey and no that should not automatically scare you away.

The fat cork cap bottle is also a nice touch that I always enjoy pouring from, and neat, w/ water or drafted into a OF, Manhattan, Derby or Sidecar look for this bottle at a good price and you won't have gone wrong. Cheers!
Very spicy throughout.  Strong alcohol taste as well.  Gift from Xmas 2019
Caramel on the nose and in the glass. Not a bad bourbon but not a great one either. Would drink again
Enjoyed it better as a mixer.
One of my favorite mixing whiskeys. A drop of Paychaud’s and a splash of Cointreau with a big ice cube in a Waterford tumbler. Happy New Year!
I much prefer the straight Rye
Mellows quick with ice.  Not very complex.

Underrated by some. I truly enjoyed this. It is sweet which I assume is the bourbon side. There is a strong note of honey. The rye side makes it a very easy drink especially on ice. I think putting it on ice makes it better. It almost cuts it so to speak. There are also notes of vanilla. True vanilla extract. Comparable to crown Royal IMO. Could be a go to of mine from here on out.
This high rye would be better used as a mixer. Spicy..maybe a little too spicy
Nice! But it is fiery. A little much for me on its own. Better in a cocktail.

I have has the opportunity to try this offering from Redemption and while not the best I have ever had it is a solid Bourbon and its flavor is quite pleasant. I bought this a few weeks ago and did not know what to expect so here goes the review. It has a lighter color than Henry McKenna BiB or Evan Williams BiB and the nose is not as sweet. It reminds me of David Nicholson Reserve they are both spicey and robust Bourbons. It makes a very solid Old Fashioned and Manhatten however, it is a little young to sip in the summer. Overall this is a very good choice for a home bar or as a substitute for some Rye whiskeys. I do not see it very often around where I live but I will buy it again as space comes available in my bar.

Thin nose that leads with ethanol. A little caramel and vanilla on the nose. Nice sweet and spicy taste. The spicy finish hits you and stays a bit but dissipates fairly quickly. Once again, for my budget a nice $20 buy. But probably not more.
Definitely get lots of caramel and anise, but the profile is not as rounded as I generally prefer
